subject: Investor Relations
Sentiment Analysis
Natural Language Processing
Financial Communications
AI Analytics
dublin_core.description: An interactive MicroSim demonstrating how lexicon-based sentiment analysis works on financial text, using a simplified approach inspired by the Loughran-McDonald dictionary. Students can input or select financial text samples and observe real-time sentiment scoring with visual feedback.

educational.topic: Sentiment Analysis and Natural Language Processing in IR
learning_objectives: Understand how lexicon-based sentiment analysis calculates scores from financial text
Apply sentiment analysis concepts to evaluate investor communications
Analyze how specific word choices impact overall sentiment scores
Evaluate the strengths and limitations of lexicon-based sentiment methods
prerequisites: Basic understanding of investor relations communications
Familiarity with earnings calls and press releases
Awareness that AI can analyze text for patterns
assessment_opportunities: Can students explain why certain texts score as positive/negative?
Can they predict approximate scores before analyzing new text?
Can they draft communications with intentional sentiment targets?
Can they articulate limitations of lexicon-based approaches?

visualizations.description: Color-coded horizontal gauge showing sentiment score from -1.0 (red/negative) to +1.0 (green/positive)
visualizations.purpose: Provides immediate visual feedback on overall sentiment

visualizations.description: Shows total words, positive word count, negative word count, and net sentiment
visualizations.purpose: Breaks down the components of the sentiment calculation

visualizations.description: Displays the specific positive and negative words found in the text
visualizations.purpose: Shows which words contributed to the sentiment score

simulation_model.methodology: Word-counting approach using financial sentiment dictionaries

variables.name: totalWords
variables.description: Total word count in input text

lexicons.source: Simplified subset inspired by Loughran-McDonald financial dictionary

assumptions: All positive words have equal weight (+1)
All negative words have equal weight (-1)
Word context and negation are not considered
Scoring is based solely on word presence, not frequency
limitations: Does not detect negation (e.g., 'not bad' treated as negative)
Cannot understand context (e.g., 'address concerns' vs 'concerns remain')
Simplified lexicon much smaller than production systems (40 vs 2000+ words)
Does not account for word position or sentence structure
No handling of domain-specific phrases or multi-word expressions

pedagogical_context.instructional_strategy: Guided exploration with sample texts followed by open experimentation
pedagogical_context.cognitive_load: Medium - focuses on single concept but requires understanding of text analysis
learning_progression: Observe pre-loaded examples to see range of sentiment scores
Experiment with adding/removing words to see impact
Critically evaluate limitations through edge cases
common_misconceptions: Sentiment analysis is perfectly objective (it reflects lexicon design choices)
More negative words always means negative overall (context and density matter)
Simple word counting is sufficient for production systems (modern systems use ML)
Negative sentiment is always bad for IR (transparency can build trust)
